video.title: Intro to Angular 5 Tutorial
video.description:
Introduction to Angular. Angular is a TypeScript-based open-source front-end web application platform led by the Angular Team at Google and by a community of individuals and corporations.

Check out Dylan Israel's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5Wi_NYysX-LfcqT3Hq9Faw

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Jack Alvarez
topLevelComment.text: any one see the irony of his desktop background

replies.author: IncomingLegend
replies.text: what? the classical gears that will never work in that position? or is it something else?

topLevelComment.author: CHBY
topLevelComment.text: I appreciate the efforts but literally have no idea what's happening here....you're going 100 mph

topLevelComment.author: Relaxation museum
topLevelComment.text: wow u r going soo fast :/

topLevelComment.author: PioneerX
topLevelComment.text: This wasn't bad but just my thoughts on how to make it better. It would have been better had you done a high level overview of everything @02:04 before jumping into long portions of tedious angular coding where the viewer doesn't yet have the knowledge to fully understand what you're coding and why, what the angular file structure is and why, etc.  Also clearly delineate to the viewer when you're moving on from one topic to the next, it felt very meandering and I was like oh we're on services now? Are we done with components? Jumping back and forth between major topics a lot was confusing.

topLevelComment.author: StarGazing

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: Did you add the service to app.module.ts? See 26:42.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: Most of the info in this video also applies to 6.

replies.author: Mohammed Khan
replies.text: you are right david, 90 percent are looking for people who can convert existing angular 1 projects into angular 4, And Chris for front end devs I think knowing React is perfectly enough to get a job, but most job posting never ask for just react, know the unit testing framework, know how to make serverless front end applications using aws or firebase. Most angular job postings will require you to know Java and the spring framework or the mean stack

replies.author: Chris Kavanagh
replies.text: I understand, as I know several Frameworks. I was really alluding to the job market for front end devs. Is Angular the way to go as far as number of jobs in the market?

replies.author: David Basil
replies.text: 90 percent of angular jobs out there are for angular 1

replies.author: Mohammed Khan
replies.text: also, once you know one framework it doesnt take that long to get to know another, i prefer angular because it was a much easier move from Java to typescript but I will end up learning react because I want to have more tools in my box

replies.author: Mohammed Khan
replies.text: me? no i work for amex, currently our full stack is spring boot, node, angular 4. I interviewed with many other banks and insurance companies and usually thats the stack, the only time react has come up is when i try for data visualization or startup companies. There are enterprise companies like goldman sachs that are trying out react, as hot as the framework is, it really depends where and what field your trying to get into
